    A Subset of New Platinum Antitumor Agents Kills Cells by a Multimodal Mechanism of Action Also Involving Changes in the Organization of the Microtubule Cytoskeleton

    Abstract

    The substitution inert platinum agent [Pt(1S,2S-diaminocyclohexane)(5,6-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline)]2+ (56MeSS, 5) is a potent cytotoxic metallodrug. In contrast to conventional cisplatin or oxaliplatin, the mechanism of action (MoA) of 5 is fundamentally different. However, details of the mechanism by which the 5,6-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline ligand contributes to the cytotoxicity of 5 and its derivatives have not been sufficiently clarified so far. Here, we show that 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives exhibit an intriguing potency in the triple-negative breast cancer cells MDA-MB-231. Moreover, we show that the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 act by multimodal MoA resulting in the global biological effects, that is, they damage nuclear DNA, reduce the mitochondrial membrane potential, induce the epigenetic processes, and last but not least, the data provide evidence that changes in the organization of cytoskeleton networks are functionally important for 5 and its derivatives, in contrast to clinically used platinum cytostatics, to kill cancer cells.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Platinum coordination compounds, such as cisplatin, carboplatin, and oxaliplatin (1), are some of the most widely used chemotherapeutics for the treatment of human tumors. However, their clinical use is associated with several drawbacks(1) involving inherent and acquired resistance, adverse side effects, a narrow spectrum of activity, low bioavailability, and the fact that no single-platinum agent is equally effective against all cancer types. These disadvantages triggered a search for novel cytotoxic platinum coordination compounds resulting in the design and synthesis of a large number of platinum complexes that were tested for anticancer activity, and their mechanism of action (MoA) has been extensively investigated by laboratories worldwide.
    The most extensive research on the cellular and molecular MoAs that underlie efficacy were performed first on the approved drugs, cisplatin, carboplatin and 1. The main steps of the MoA of cisplatin and its derivatives involve cellular accumulation, activation by aquation, the formation of DNA adducts (cross-links) that distort the DNA, and their cellular processing leading to cell death.(2) Thus, one of the strategies for the design of new anticancer platinum drugs is to change the outcome of one or more of these steps, that is, to improve cellular accumulation and alter the DNA binding mode and, consequently, cellular processing of DNA adducts. In addition, attempts have been made to design complexes that bind to targets different from DNA. Clinicians try to overcome resistance to existing anticancer platinum drugs by combination chemotherapy, treating the patients with platinum drugs together with drugs that act by different mechanisms. For instance, the introduction of cisplatin or 1 in combination chemotherapy helped advance cure rates.(3,4) Thus, the current trend in clinical research has gradually shifted from a focus on monotherapy to combination therapy for enhanced treatment efficacy.(5−7) In combining drugs, we face the problem that different drugs have different solubilities and pharmacokinetics.(8,9) Notwithstanding, the design and development of new single cytostatics that simultaneously affect more distinct oncogenic targets appears to be a promising strategy, which is more profitable in comparison with the development of a combination of two or more drugs.
    One approach to designing multiaction cytotoxic platinum agents is based on Pt(IV) prodrugs that simultaneously release, after their reduction inside the cancer cell, an active Pt(II) drug and bioactive moieties.(10) These six-coordinate octahedral complexes are derivatives of square planar Pt(II) complexes containing axial ligands that can enhance hydrophobicity and consequently cellular accumulation, increase solubility, modify rates of reduction, and affect cellular target(s) other than DNA.(11) After they enter the tumor cell with the internal hypoxic environment, these inert Pt(IV) prodrugs are activated by reduction releasing the cytotoxic Pt(II) complex and the two axial bioactive ligands that can affect different intracellular targets and act by MoA(s) different from that of the Pt(II) complex.(12) Unquestionable advantages of these Pt(IV) prodrugs are as follows: (i) they contain the combination of different drugs, each acting by a different MoA, in a single molecule with a single pharmacokinetic profile; (ii) they are kinetically inert in comparison with their Pt(II) counterparts, minimizing undesirable interactions with nucleophiles in extracellular milieu, which may reduce side effects, and can enhance bioavailability; and (iii) they can be administered orally.(13,14)
    A number of novel Pt(IV) prodrugs that simultaneously release, besides the active Pt(II) complex, one or more different bioactive moieties inside the cancer cell were introduced (for instance, see refs (15−25)). Their cytotoxicity against cancer cells in vitro and also, in some cases, in vivo was significantly better than that of cisplatin or its clinically used derivatives. Quite recently, a novel Pt(IV) dinuclear complex (Figure 1), which acted as a “quadruple action” cytotoxic prodrug, was designed, and some aspects of its MoA were determined.(26)
    This Pt(IV) prodrug released four different bioactive moieties in cancer cells: cisplatin, dichloroacetate (DCA), phenylbutyrate (PhB), and [Pt(1S,2S-diaminocyclohexane) (5,6-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline)]2+ (56MeSS, 5 in Figure 2). The activity of the quadruple-action platinum(IV) prodrug shown in Figure 1 was attributed among others to its enhanced accumulation in cancer cells and synergism between DNA platination (cisplatin), histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibition (PhB), action on the mitochondria (DCA), and the effects of 5. Intriguingly, 5 is a very potent cytotoxic metallointercalator exhibiting submicromolar IC50 values against a variety of cancer cells.(27) In contrast, the MoA of 5 is fundamentally different from cisplatin,(26) but the details of the mechanism by which the 5,6-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline ligand (5,6-Me2phen) contributes to the cytotoxicity of the complexes containing this ligand have not been sufficiently clarified so far. Multiaction anticancer Pt(IV) prodrugs hitherto investigated, the working hypotheses, MoAs, the basic chemistry of these complexes, and the interpretations of the biological data were very recently reviewed.(28)
    Here, we describe, with the aim to contribute to understanding the role of the 5,6-Me2phen ligand in the mechanisms of cytotoxicity of Pt(IV) “multiaction” prodrugs, the synthesis and biochemical and antiproliferative properties of a series of multiaction Pt(IV) prodrugs (Figure 2). These new Pt(IV) complexes release different bioactive agents in tumor cells, such as 5, PhB, and octanoic acid (OA), that act on DNA and the mitochondria, are inhibitors of HDACs and act as a DNA hypermethylating agent(18,21) (Figure 2). The properties of the latter series of Pt(IV) prodrugs were compared with the series of very similar compounds, Pt(IV) derivatives of 1, which thus contained the leaving oxalate instead of the 5,6-Me2phen ligand.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Antiproliferative Activity Screening

    The antiproliferative properties of the compounds evaluated in the present work were screened on the panel of malignant and nonmalignant cell lines using the colorimetric MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay and 72 h of the drug incubation period. Results expressed as IC50 values (concentration of the compound that causes death in 50% of cells calculated from dose–survival curves) are shown in Table 1.

    Notably, significant differences exist in the antiproliferative activity of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 1 and corresponding derivatives of 5 (Table 1). Interestingly, the Pt(IV) derivatives of 1 and 5 were established to have antiproliferative activity with few exceptions similar or markedly better than their Pt(II) counterparts. The Pt(IV) derivatives of 1 displayed low to moderate toxicity against all cell lines depending on the type of the axial ligands. While the dual-action Pt(IV) derivatives of 1 containing only one bioactive ligand (PhB or OA) exhibited relatively low antiproliferative activity, a marked increase was observed for triple-action 4 containing two different bioactive axial ligands.
    Conversely, the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 exhibited impressive potency at markedly lower concentrations (submicromolar) than the analogous Pt(IV) derivatives of 1. Moreover, the antiproliferative activity of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 does not depend on the type of axial ligand(s). The potency of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 appears to stem primarily from the Pt(II) precursor, [Pt(SS-DACH)(5,6-Me2phen)] (DACH = 1S,2S-diaminocyclohexane), that is common to all these compounds, rather than from the bioactive axial ligand(s). These observations emphasize the fact that, unlike the Pt(IV) derivatives of cisplatin and 1, where bioactive axial ligands can significantly improve the cytotoxicity compared to the Pt(II) precursors, in the case of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5, the axial ligands have negligible effects on the antiproliferative activity.
    The markedly higher antiproliferative activity of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives in comparison with that of those based on 1 (Table 1) deserves further discussion. Both groups of compounds contain enantiomeric DACH ligand; the DACH ligand in the compounds based on 1 is RR-DACH, whereas SS-DACH is contained in the compounds based on 5. Thus, it is possible to speculate that the considerable differences in antiproliferative activities observed for the compounds based on 1 and 5 (Table 1) might also be a consequence of different enantiomericity of their amine ligands. However, this eventuality is unlikely since it has been found(29−31) that the platinum(II)–oxalate complex with RR-DACH (1) was more active than the corresponding complexes with SS-DACH,(29−31) whereas platinum(II)–complex 5 with RR-DACH was less active than the corresponding complexes with SS-DACH.(32)
    An intriguing potency of the compounds based on 5 was observed for breast cancer cells MDA-MB-231 and colon carcinoma cells HCT-116 [for instance, the IC50 values found for the investigated Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 were as low as 0.06–0.07 μM (Table 1)], that is, by approximately two orders of magnitude lower than the IC50 values found for clinically used anticancer platinum drugs. A common feature of these cancer cells is that both carry RAS mutation that can cause the tumor to become resistant to drugs usually used to treat these types of cancer cells. Thus, these results are also consistent with those reported recently for the treatment of other KRAS-mutated cancer cells with the dinuclear quadruple-action Pt(IV) prodrug (Figure 1) that also contained the portion of 5.(26) However, studies aimed at revealing the reasons why the RAS-mutated cancer cells exhibit specific sensitivity to the treatment with the compounds based on 5 have not been carried out so far.
    Interestingly, the triple-negative breast cancer cells MDA-MB-231 are highly aggressive cells that are resistant to a number of chemotherapeutics including cisplatin. Hence, it is important for the design and development of the chemotherapeutics efficient in treating this type of breast cancer to understand molecular mechanisms responsible for the response of these breast cancer cells to antitumor agents. Therefore, we also used here MDA-MB-231 cells to further investigate the role of the 5,6-Me2phen ligand in the mechanisms of cytotoxicity of Pt(IV) multiaction prodrugs.

    Cellular Accumulation

    Cellular accumulation of 1, 5, and their Pt(IV) derivatives in the triple-negative breast cancer MDA-MB-231 cell line was studied to investigate a possible relationship between the cellular uptake and in vitro cytotoxicity of the platinum complexes. Cellular concentrations of platinum from 1, 5, and their Pt(IV) derivatives were determined by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) after 6 h of exposure to the complexes at the concentrations of 0.8, 2, and 5 μM. These concentrations were chosen as a compromise between the limit of quantitation of platinum in our biological samples by ICP-MS and the high toxicity of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5, which could compromise the results. As the investigated compounds exhibit a rather broad range of IC50 values (Table 1) to assess the ability of these compounds to enter the cells, short (6 h) incubation periods and equimolar concentrations were chosen. All compounds were tested with the MDA-MB-231 cells at concentrations of 2 μM and either 800 nM or 5 μM depending on their cytotoxicity (Table 1). The results are summarized in Table 2.
    Table 2. Cellular Platinum Accumulation in MDA-MB-231 and log P (Octanol/Water) Values Obtained by the Shake Flask Method
     Total ng Pt/106 cellsa,c 
    platinum complex800 nM / 6 h2 μM / 6 h5 μM / 6 hlog Pb,c

    2 1.3 ± 0.12.9 ± 0.20.02 ± 0.01
    3 1.5 ± 0.12.94 ± 0.050.30 ± 0.04

    It was demonstrated that a higher accumulation of Pt drugs generally correlates with enhanced hydrophobicity, although the involvement of active and facilitated transport mechanisms in the cellular accumulation of the investigated Pt(IV) complexes and 1 can substantially affect their final cellular accumulation.(33,34) A measure of hydrophobicity of the metallodrugs was determined using their partition coefficient (log P) values for 1-octanol/water partition(17,35,36) (Table 2).
    Despite the significant difference in their log P values, 1 (−1.89) and its Pt(IV) derivatives, 2 (0.02) and 3 (0.30), accumulated in a similar extent when the cells were treated for 6 h with the compounds at a concentration of 2 or 5 μM. The presence of two bioactive axial ligands (PhB and OA) in 4 led to a significant increase in platinum taken up by the cells (19- to 26-fold) when the cells were treated for 6 h with the compounds at a concentration of 2 μM. The bioactive axial ligands in 4 transformed this Pt(IV) derivative of 1 to the most hydrophobic compound of the group 1–4 (Table 2). On the other hand, this enhancement of hydrophobicity of 4 was not so high as one would expect considering a marked enhancement of its cellular accumulation and cytotoxicity (Tables 1 and 2). Thus, the cellular accumulation and cytotoxicity of compounds of the 1–4 series do not appear to reflect their hydrophobicity.
    We also confirmed some correlation between the hydrophobicity (log P), cellular accumulation, and cytotoxicity for 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives (Table 2). Interestingly, although 5, 6, and 7 are hydrophilic, they accumulate significantly more efficiently than 2, 3, and 4 that are all lipophilic, suggesting that structural factors other than lipophilicity might contribute to the cellular accumulation of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives. This may be due to the square planar [Pt(SS-DACH)(5,6-Me2phen)] moiety and/or to the positive charge (2+) of these complexes.
    Cellular accumulation of platinum was also investigated to evaluate the distribution of platinum species in different subcellular compartments. MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with 1, 5, and their Pt(IV) derivatives (2 μM each) for 6 h, and the cells were fractionated into four pools: membrane, cytosol, nucleus, and cytoskeleton. The platinum levels in each pool were measured by ICP-MS. The results are presented in Figure 3.
    The extent of accumulation of 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives into the cell membrane fraction was markedly greater than that of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives, accounting for 54 vs 13% (1 vs 5), 61 vs 14% (2 vs 6), 57 vs 14% (3 vs 7), and 71 vs 15% (4 vs 8) of the total Pt associated with the cell. In contrast, 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives accumulated markedly more into the cytoskeleton fraction in comparison with 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives, accounting for 76 vs 21% (5 vs 1), 76 vs 10% (6 vs 2), 76 vs 15% (7 vs 3), and 73 vs 7% (8 vs 4) of the total Pt associated with the cell. Thus, while 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives were most abundant in the cell membrane fraction, 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives accumulated with a marked preference into the cytoskeleton. These data, and particularly the fact that the most lipophilic compound (8) does not accumulate in the membrane, support the hypothesis that the hitherto unclear role of the 5,6-Me2phen ligand in the mechanisms of cytotoxicity of 5 and its Pt(IV) multiaction prodrugs consists in targeting these platinum complexes toward the cytoskeleton.

    Impedance-Based Time-Dependent Cell Response Profiling

    Given the above findings, we investigated the influence of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives on the cytoskeleton structure and function. First, we analyzed the cell growth profiles obtained by RTCA (real-time cell analyzer) and compared them with the profiles acquired for cells treated with cytoskeleton-modifying compounds. Impedance-based time-dependent cell response profiling has been used as the predictive method for the mechanism of biological action of bioactive compounds; compounds with similar biological activity often produce similar signature time-dependent cell response profiles (TCRPs) so that the TCRPs make it possible to recognize the MoA of the investigated agents.(37,38) The TCRPs for MDA-MB-231 treated with 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives (bottom row of panels in Figure 4) could be coclustered with those of another microtubule (MT)-modulating agents.(37,39)
    Also of note is that the TCRPs for MDA-MB-231 treated with 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives (bottom row of panels in Figure 4) were different from those for MDA-MB-231 treated with 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives (upper row of panels in Figure 4); the latter TCRPs were indicative of the compounds interfering with DNA synthesis or repair.(37,39) Altogether, the TCRPs obtained for the investigated complexes based on 5 (bottom row in Figure 4) are consistent with the view and support the hypothesis that a possible MoA of these complexes involves alterations of the MT cytoskeleton. On the other hand, the results shown in Figure 3 also indicate that a small fraction of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives is also associated with the cell nucleus. This finding might indicate that the MoA of these complexes includes, in some extent, DNA damage by its modification by 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives as well. The latter conclusion is supported by the results (Table S1) demonstrating that the treatment of MDA-MB-231 cells with the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 resulted in DNA damage caused by its association with a platinum compound.

    The Role of DNA Modification and Reduction of Pt(IV) Complexes to Their Pt(II) Derivatives

    A biological tool to establish whether DNA is the target of cytotoxic agents takes advantage of the fact that drugs exhibit higher toxicity in cells, which are deficient in DNA repair.(40) Mutant Chinese hamster ovary CHO-K1 cells MMC-2, carrying the ERCC3/XPB mutation, which are deficient in DNA nucleotide excision repair, were distinctly more sensitive to killing mainly by 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives compared with the wild-type cells (Table 3).
    Table 3. Cytotoxicity Data [IC50 Mean Values (μM)] Obtained by MTT Test for Chinese Hamster Ovary CHO-K1 Cell Line (Wild Type) and Its Mutant Cell Line MMC-2 Deficient in DNA Repaira
    platinum complexCHO-K1MMC-2Fb
    119 ± 11.9 ± 0.110.0
    261 ± 95.7 ± 0.210.7
    348 ± 64.9 ± 0.79.8
    412 ± 21.1 ± 0.210.9
    58 ± 14.9 ± 0.51.6
    611 ± 28 ± 11.4
    711 ± 27.1 ± 0.91.5
    89 ± 16.1 ± 0.51.5
    a

    The drug-treatment period was 72 h. The results are expressed as mean values ± SD from three independent experiments each performed in triplicate.

    b

    F = factor defined as IC50 (NER-efficient, CHO-K1)/IC50 (NER-deficient, MMC-2).

    These results are consistent with the hypothesis that unrepaired DNA damage contributes to the cytotoxicity of 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives. In contrast, we observed that there was a markedly lower difference in the sensitivity of mutant MMC-2 and wild-type CHO-K1 to killing by 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives (Table 3). This result suggests that DNA damage by these compounds may play a less decisive role in the mechanism of their antiproliferative activity very likely due to their markedly lower accumulation in the cell nucleus in comparison with 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives (Figure 3).
    Designing multiaction antitumor platinum agents is based on the stability of the kinetically inert Pt(IV) prodrugs outside the cell and on their activation by reduction inside the cell, resulting in the simultaneous release of the active Pt(II) drug and axial bioactive moieties. Due to the very low intracellular concentrations of these cytotoxic prodrugs, there are no analytical or spectroscopic procedures that can directly monitor the oxidation state of the Pt inside cells. Therefore, a support for the view that Pt(IV) prodrugs, such as those investigated in our study, are activated by reduction inside the cell rests in on indirect evidence demonstrating that incubation in a cell-free medium of the kinetically inert Pt(IV) compounds based on 5 or 1 with isolated DNA did not result in its platination (shown in Figure S1). In contrast, if these Pt(IV) compounds were incubated with DNA in the presence of a known reductant, such as ascorbic acid, then an extensive association of platinum with DNA was observed (Figure S1). It implies that the Pt(IV) compounds based on both 5 and 1 can modify DNA only after their reduction or, in other words, that the reduction of the Pt(IV) compounds based on both 5 and 1 is a prerequisite for DNA modification. Next, we isolated DNA from MDA-MB-231 cells treated with the 5-based Pt(IV) compounds and found that this DNA was modified by platinum (Table S1).
    The importance of the reduction of Pt(IV) platinum compounds containing biologically active axial ligands also follows from the previously published results describing the MoA of closely related Pt(IV) prodrugs (for review, see a recently published work(28)) and those showing that Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 very similar to those investigated in the present study were stable in human serum for 40 h at 37 °C, attesting to their extracellular stability.(41) Also, importantly, the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 containing HDAC inhibitors (valproate (VPA) or PhB) in the axial positions exhibited cellular downregulation of HDACs that was absent when there were innocent ligands in the axial positions. This attests to a cellular reduction of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 because a cell-free medium Pt(IV) prodrug containing VPA axial ligand(s) was unable to inhibit HDAC activity, whereas if this Pt(IV) prodrug was reduced by ascorbic acid, inhibition of HDAC activity was observed.(17,42) Collectively, the only reasonable explanation of these observations is that the Pt(IV) compounds based on 5 and 1 investigated in the present study were intracellularly reduced to allow DNA damage by its modification by platinum, that is, one of the modes of action of these multimodal antitumor agents.

    Cell-Cycle Profiles of MDA-MB-231 Cells

    To further investigate the hypothesis that a possible MoA of the investigated 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives involves the disruption of the microtubule cytoskeleton, we investigated the cell-cycle profiles of MDA-MB-231 cells modified with the investigated platinum compounds. Several articles report that MT modification coincides with the induction of cell cycle G2/M arrest.(43−46) Therefore, we investigated the cell-cycle profiles of MDA-MB-231 cells treated with the investigated platinum compounds. MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with the platinum compounds for 12, 24, and 48 h at the concentrations corresponding to their IC30 values (found for these compounds in MDA-MB-231 cells treated for 72 h) (Figure 5 and Figure S2).
    Longer treatment resulted in a significant reduction in the percentage of cells in the S phase (Figure 5B) and an increase in the percentage in the G2/M phase (Figure 5A). The number of cells in the G2/M region after 48 h of treatment increased significantly to 30 ± 2% to 44 ± 2%, in comparison with that of solvent-treated control (16 ± 1%), indicating the disruption of the MT cytoskeleton in MDA-MB-231 cells by 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives.
    Subsequently, we examined, for comparative purposes, the cell-cycle profiles of MDA-MB-231 cells treated for 24 h with 1 and its Pt(IV) derivatives at their concentrations corresponding to their IC30 values (found for these compounds in MDA-MB-231 cells treated for 72 h). In contrast to the cell-cycle profiles recorded for 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives (Figure 5), the platinum compounds of the group 1–4 arrested cells mainly in the S phase (Figure S3), similar to cisplatin,(47,48) and slightly in the G2/M phase as well. These results suggest that a mechanism of MDA-MB-231 cell death induced by complexes of the group 1–4 relies on DNA damage signaling consistent with the results of impedance-based time-dependent cell response profiling (Figure 4, top row) and cytotoxicity data obtained for the Chinese hamster ovary CHO-K1 cell line (wild type) and its mutant cell line MMC-2 deficient in DNA repair (Table 3). Conversely, these results also underscore the ability of complexes of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives to kill MDA-MB-231 cells by a fundamentally different mechanism.

    The Effect of Tubulin and Actin Inhibitors

    The previous experiments suggested that 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives can interfere with the components of the cytoskeleton. Among others, actin filaments and microtubules represent two major groups of cytoskeletal proteins. It has been reported previously(49,50) that simultaneous action of two agents results in superadditive or synergistic effects if the two drugs cooperate on the target(s) involved in the same process. Therefore, to find out which cytoskeleton component is targeted by 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives, the antiproliferative effect of the simultaneous treatment of 5 with drugs affecting either actin (phalloidin and cytochalasin D) or tubulin (nocodazole and vinblastine) was examined. Phalloidin functions by stabilizing filamentous actin and inhibits its depolymerization, whereas cytochalasin D is an inhibitor of actin polymerization. Vinblastin and nocodazole inhibit the assembly of microtubules. The MDA-MB-231 cells were simultaneously treated with 5 and the particular inhibitor in their equimolar (1:1) or equitoxic (corresponding to the respective IC50 values) concentrations. The antiproliferative effect was then evaluated by the MTT method. The combination index (CI) method developed by Chou and Talalay(51,52) was used to confirm and quantify the synergism observed for the co-treatment. CI < 1 is indicative of synergy, CI > 1 indicates antagonism, and a CI of ∼1 (0.9–1.1) is considered an additive response to the combination of drugs. The CI values for the activity of 5 and actin or tubulin affecting drug combinations were calculated using CompuSyn software (Combo Syn, Inc., USA), and these are summarized in Table 4. At least six entries of dose–effect relationships were employed for each drug combination.
    Table 4. Combination Index (CI) Values of Antiproliferative Activity after 72 h Treatment of MDA-MB-231 Cells with 5 and Actin/Tubulin Affecting Drug Combinationsa
    inhibitorCI
    vinblastine0.775 (1:1)0.809 (100:1)
    nocodazole0.510 (1:1)0.662 (2:1)
    phalloidin1.146 (1:1)0.984 (1:10)
    cytochalasin D0.979 (1:1)1.035 (1:2)
    a

    The ratio (5:drug) is shown in brackets.

    As indicated, 5 and tubulin inhibitors vinblastine and nocodazole were synergistic in MDA-MB-231 cells, with CI values ranging from 0.51 to 0.81. The CI somewhat increased for vinblastine as compared with the nocodazole but was still within the mathematical index of synergy. In contrast, the combination of actin targeting inhibitors phalloidin or cytochalasin D with 5 yielded CI values around 1, which is considered as an additive effect. Thus, the data implies that tubulin rather than actin is likely affected by 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives. Therefore, in the next experiments, the effects of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives on tubulin were investigated in further detail.

    Organization of the Structural Network within the Cytoplasm of MDA-MB-231 Cells

    As platinum from 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives preferentially accumulated in the cytoskeleton fraction of MDA-MB-231 cells, we next sought to gain more insight into the influence that 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives may exert on the organization of the structural network (cytoskeleton) within the cell’s cytoplasm. To do so, we treated the MDA-MB-231 cells with 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives, stained with monoclonal antibodies directed against α-tubulin, and visualized by confocal microscopy (Figure S4). In nontreated cells, MTs extended continuously through the cytoplasm and formed an extensive intracellular network. The treatment with 5 and its investigated Pt(IV) derivatives at the concentrations corresponding to the IC50 values (72 h; Table 1) for 16 h induced changes in the architecture of MT networks through retraction to the perinuclear region when compared with untreated cells. This specific distribution of irregular MT fragments in MDA-MB-231 cells is consistent with the observation that 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives cause cell cycle G2/M arrest as previously demonstrated for other agents capable of disturbing tubulin assembly.(44,53) Thus, the capability of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives to induce changes in the architecture of cytoskeleton networks presents new insights into their MoA. In this connection, it is relevant to mention that there is a class of anticancer drugs that alter MT dynamics, that is, MT stabilizers and depolymerizers, which bind to established tubulin-binding sites.(54) However, it is difficult to ascribe the effects of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives to their ability to affect the MT dynamics since the MDA-MB-231 cells treated with 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives showed no appreciable change in the MT size (Figure S4). Moreover, drugs affecting MT dynamics are supposed to change the kinetics of MT polymerization and the polymerized steady-state level. Therefore, we investigated MT polymerization kinetics in a cell-free medium by turbidity measurements.(55)

    Tubulin Polymerization and Depolymerization Assay

    Compounds that interact with tubulin often alter its polymerization by enhancing the growth of microtubules (such as paclitaxel)(56) or by destabilizing and depolymerizing microtubules (such as nocodazole).(57) To elucidate the effect of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives on tubulin polymerization in vitro (in cell-free media), the HTS-Tubulin Polymerization Assay Biochem Kit was employed. The assay is based on the fact that light is scattered by microtubules to the extent that is proportional to the concentration of microtubule polymer.(58,59) Thus, the polymerization of porcine tubulin in the presence or absence of the Pt compounds was followed by turbidimetry as an increase in absorbance at 340 nm at 37 °C. The control assembly curve (tubulin in the absence of 5 or 8) displayed typical patterns of microtubule polymerization (Figure 6A and B, solid curves) with a flat plateau in the last phase of polymerization, indicating the steady-state equilibrium of polymerization and depolymerization reactions. In the presence of 5 (Figure 6A, dashed and dotted curves) or 8 (Figure 6B, dashed and dotted curves), the slopes of the assembly curves dropped down, indicating a decrease in polymerization rate. Importantly, in a later reaction interval, the plateau was no longer stable, and the light was scattered to the extent higher than that for the control, thus indicating aggregation or bundling.(60)
    The effect of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives on depolymerization was also assessed by turbidimetric measurement. The porcine brain tubulin was allowed to polymerize in the presence or absence of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives at 37 °C for 80 min. After that period, the temperature was regulated to slowly decrease (0.5 °C/min), and scattered light was measured at 340 nm. If microtubules are cooled, then they depolymerize into stable αβ-tubulin dimers accompanied by a decrease in light scattering (Figure 6C, solid line). However, the microtubules formed in the presence of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives disassembled more slowly than the control, unaffected microtubules (shown for 5 in Figure 6C, dashed, dash-dotted, and dotted lines). Thus, 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives also interfered with tubulin depolymerization, thus affecting microtubule assembly/disassembly dynamics.
    Interestingly, the results of the experiments performed in a cell-free medium (Figure 6) show that there was no substantial difference in the capability of platinum(II) complex 5 and its Pt(IV) derivative 8 to induce changes in the organization of tubulin cytoskeleton networks. Thus, this result is consistent with the view and supports the hypothesis that the reduction of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 does not have to take place to observe their effect on the MT dynamics.

    Whole Cell Analysis of Microtubule by Flow Cytometry

    The experiments performed using whole cell methods make it possible to examine the mechanism of action of the investigated compounds under conditions closer to the situation in vivo in comparison with the experiments performed in cell-free media. The experiments aimed at microtubule stabilization or destabilization in cells affected by the investigated agents can be performed by means of confocal microscopy(61) or flow cytometry(62) along with a fluorescently labeled antibody to α-tubulin. Thus, the flow cytometry-based technique was also used for the analysis of tubulin polymerization in the presence of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives. Flow cytometry can be used to quantitatively determine the polymerized tubulin, which makes it possible to easily detect compounds that affect tubulin polymerization.(62) Briefly, MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated with compounds for 3 h at the concentrations of 20, 40, or 80 μM, tubulin monomers were washed out of the cells using a mild lysis buffer, and the microtubule network in cells was stabilized by treatment with glutaraldehyde. After quenching glutaraldehyde, samples were exposed to an FITC-labeled tubulin antibody and analyzed. Under this experimental approach, it is expected that compounds effective in the destabilization of tubulin polymerization decrease fluorescence compared to the control; in contrast, compounds that stabilize microtubules increase fluorescence, reflecting the change in the amount of tubulin in the polymerized microtubules.(62)
    The treatment of MDA-MB-231 cells with 5 or 8 resulted in a significant dose-dependent increase in fluorescence, indicating an accrual of tubulin mass in the treated cells compared to untreated control cells (Figure 6D). The data plausibly correspond with the findings mentioned above in cell-free media and support the view that 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives can act through the disruption of the tubulin/microtubule dynamics.

    Atomic Force Microscopy

    Atomic force microscopy (AFM) has been previously used to visualize the effect of small molecules on microtubule morphology. We, therefore, employed this method to reveal how 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives can impact the shape and structure of polymeric microtubules. Porcine brain tubulin was polymerized in the absence or the presence of 5 or 8, fixed on mica, and analyzed by AFM.
    As shown in Figure 7, long narrow microtubules were yielded by tubulin polymerization in the absence of the platinum agents (Figure 7A).
    The presence of either 5 (Figure 7B) or 8 (Figure 7C) in the polymerization reaction influences the appearance of the final product. Nonfibrillar condensed structures such as bundles, knots, or coils were formed if the polymerization occurred in the presence of the tested compounds. Thus, it appears that 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives do not stop the polymerization or disintegrate the arising microtubules but induce the structural changes of the final polymeric product. The bundling and/or aggregation could be responsible for slower depolymerization of microtubules as detected in both cell-free media and living cells (vide supra).

    Analysis of Mitochondrial Membrane Potential

    Treatment of cancer cells with numerous antitumor metallodrugs cause mitochondrial transmembrane potential disruption and activates the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway.(63−65) The previous investigation of the MoA of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 containing some nonbioactive, lipophilic, and bioactive axial ligands(66) showed that some of these compounds effectively induced the hypopolarization of the mitochondrial membrane of 2008 ovarian tumor cells. However, the role of the 5,6-Me2phen ligand in the mechanisms of the hypopolarization of the mitochondrial membrane remained elusive. It was, therefore, logical to evaluate the activities of the investigated platinum compounds at the mitochondrial level in MDA-MB-231 cells as well. We used the assay based on TMRE staining similarly as described in our previous articles.(21,38,67) We found (Figure S5A) that the hypopolarization of the mitochondrial membrane induced by the Pt(II) compounds 1 (16%) and 5 (11%) was similar. The derivatization of both 1 and 5 with the bioactive PhB and OA axial ligands resulted in a substantial reduction of the mitochondrial membrane potential, and this reduction induced by 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives was similar or only slightly lower than that of the corresponding 1-based compounds (the loss of the mitochondrial membrane potential of 21–35% or 24–37% was observed for the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 or Pt(IV) derivatives of 1, respectively). In addition, the extent of the alterations in the hypopolarization of the mitochondrial membrane induced by the investigated compounds in both series of platinum compounds (1–4 and 5–8) was mainly affected by the axial ligands. These results indicate that the mechanisms connected with the hypopolarization of the mitochondrial membrane of MDA-MB-231 cells by the Pt(IV) derivatives of 1 and 5 are mainly caused by the bioactive axial ligands (PhB, OA).

    Involvement of Epigenetic Processes

    It was shown(17,18,21) that, in the case of the Pt(IV) derivatives of cisplatin and 1, having bioactive valproic acid, PhB, or OA axial ligands, their enhanced cytotoxicity is a consequence of several processes, which also involve other epigenetic processes. These processes consisted of the downregulation of HDACs (PhB)(18) or global hypermethylation of DNA (OA).(21)
    Given that the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 and 1 investigated in this work also had bioactive PhB and/or OA axial ligands, it was of interest to investigate whether 1 or 5 affect the inhibition of HDACs or DNA methylation.
    We found that the activity of HDACs in MDA-MB-231 was inhibited by 1 and 5 only very slightly; the ∼11% inhibition was observed for the inhibition by 1 and ∼5% by 5 (Figure S5B). A substantial decrease in the activity of HDACs was only observed upon treatment of the cells with Pt(IV) derivatives containing the PhB axial ligand (22% by 2 and 28% by 4; 17% by 6 and 23% by 8). The treatment of the cells with Pt(IV) derivatives of 1 or 5 containing only OA axial ligands resulted in a markedly lower inhibition of the activity of HDACs (16% by 3 or 10% by 7). Hence, inhibition of the activity of HDACs in MDA-MB-231 cells by the investigated platinum complexes depends on the presence of the PhB axial ligand; 5-based platinum complexes have diminished HDAC inhibitory activity.
    Another well-known epigenetic mechanism involved in the cytotoxic effects of Pt(IV) prodrugs is connected with DNA methylation,(21) a mechanism that inactivates tumor suppressor genes by methylating their promoters.(68) The results of our very recent study(21) demonstrated that the markedly enhanced toxic effects of the Pt(IV) derivatives of cisplatin-containing axial OA ligands were also connected with significant global hypermethylation of DNA. Therefore, we went on to characterize the ability of the platinum compounds to modulate the level of DNA methylation in MDA-MB-231 cells (Figure S5C). Only a threshold change in DNA methylation was observed for the compounds lacking the OA ligand (1, 2, 5, and 6). In contrast, the Pt(IV) derivatives of both 1 and 5 containing OA axial ligands induced considerable global DNA hypermethylation (enhancement of DNA methylation of 48–60% was observed for 3 and 4 and 20–24% for 7 and 8; Figure S5C). Thus, similar to the case of HDAC inhibition, DNA hypermethylation in MDA-MB-231 cells by the platinum complexes depends on the presence of an OA axial ligand; the platinum complexes based on 5 apparently do not affect DNA methylation.
    Collectively, triggering the epigenetic mechanisms in MDA-MB-231 cells, such as inhibition of HDAC activity or DNA hypermethylation, by the investigated platinum complexes was observed only in the case when the Pt(IV) complexes contained PhB or OA axial ligands, respectively (Figure S5B,C). Moreover, the presence of the 5,6-Me2phen ligand in the investigated platinum complexes did not contribute to the hypopolarization of the mitochondrial membrane of MDA-MB-231 cells (Figure S5A). We reasoned that the role of the 5,6-Me2phen ligand in 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives in both the hypopolarization of the mitochondrial membrane in the MDA-MB-231 cells and the epigenetic processes, which were shown to potentiate the cytotoxicity of the Pt(IV) prodrugs hitherto examined, was marginal.
    It is also especially noteworthy that MDA-MB-231 cancer cells harbor inactivating KRAS mutation that can be an important factor responsible for the resistance of these cancer cells to drugs usually used to treat breast cancer cells.(69) The RAS gene that KRAS belongs to is the most common oncogene in human cancer; mutations of KRAS are permanently activated by aberrant Ras proteins so that Ras inhibitors, in general, are being studied as a treatment of diseases involving Ras overexpression.(70) Interestingly, several studies also support a role for MTs in Ras function so that the MT network disrupting agents are efficient inhibitors of processes involving RAS overexpression, such as mitotic progression, cell proliferation, and migration.(71−74) On the basis of the results presented in this report and by analogy with the conclusions of the studies mentioned above in this paragraph, we suggest that the ability of 5-based compounds to change the organization of cytoskeleton networks in MDA-MB-231 cells is associated with their capacity to inhibit effects caused by Ras overexpression.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In conclusion, the results of this study demonstrate the exceptionally high potency of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives, in particular, in an aggressive form of breast cancer with limited treatment options, the triple-negative MDA-MB-231 cells, which are known to be highly resistant to clinically used cisplatin (Table 1). We suggest, based on the present findings, that significant components of the multimodal MoA of the substitution-inert antitumor platinum compounds based on 5 in MDA-MB-231 cells are associated with their capability to modify nuclear DNA, reduce the mitochondrial membrane potential, induce the epigenetic processes, and also change the architecture of cytoskeleton networks; the latter mechanism has not been described for other antitumor platinum compounds including those used in the clinic. In other words, changes in the organization of cytoskeleton networks is a new mechanism, which asserts itself in the antitumor effects of platinum anticancer drugs and might play an important role in conveying the preferential and high susceptibility of some cancer cells to the platinum drugs based on 5.
    Notably, the results of this study (Figures 6A,B and 7) also show that 5 and its investigated Pt(IV) derivatives do not encourage microtubule formation but block depolymerization due to the aggregation of already formed microtubules. Thus, 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives act by the different mechanism than most of so far described antimicrotubule agents. These agents either inhibit polymerization (e.g., the vinca alkaloids) or prevent depolymerization (disassembly; most commonly used agents in this subclass are paclitaxel, docetaxel, or derivatives of taxol). They act in both cases by binding to their specific binding sites in microtubules and do not induce their aggregation as the platinum compounds based on 5 discovered in our study do. An advantage of the Pt(IV) derivatives of 5 as tubulin interference agents is that they can include targeting agents, can be modified for encapsulation into delivery vehicles, and can be administered orally and combined with other drugs. Taken together, although previous studies have identified differences in the cellular response between cisplatin, 1, and their DNA binding antitumor derivatives, our report is the first to identify the causal links between drugs based on 5, changes in the architecture of cytoskeleton networks, and cell death. Thus, we conclude, based on the present results, that changes in the architecture of cytoskeleton networks are functionally important for substitution-inert platinum antitumor drugs based on 5, in contrast to clinically used conventional platinum cytostatics, to kill cancer cells. Additionally, this finding represents a promise of the development of new metal-based anticancer drugs that would be active in a spectrum of human tumors different from that attainable by the platinum drugs investigated in the clinical and preclinical research.
    It is generally accepted that microtubules (composed of tubulin) are extremely important in the process of mitosis, during which the duplicated chromosomes of a cell are separated into two identical sets before cleavage of the cell into two daughter cells. Their importance in mitosis and cell division makes microtubules (and hence tubulin) an important target for anticancer drugs so that the systematic development of a chemotype for tubulin interference is urgently needed.(75−78) Hence, the findings presented in this study may have important implications for the assessment of metal-based low-molecular-mass compounds in the clinic.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Starting Materials and Reagents

    Commercial reagents and solvents were used as received without further purification. Reaction mixtures and purified products were analyzed by HPLC on a Thermo Scientific UltimaMate 3000 station, equipped with a reversed-phase C18 column (Phenomenex Kinetex 250 × 4.6 mm, 5 μm, 100 Å). UV detection was set at 220 and 260 nm. The samples of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives were eluted with a 0–90% linear gradient of acetonitrile in water with 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) over 20 or 30 min, as indicated in the text. Reaction mixtures were separated on a Thermo Scientific UltimaMate 3000 station, equipped with a reversed-phase C18 column (Phenomenex Luna 250 × 21.2 mm, 10 μm, 100 Å). UV detection was set at 220 nm. 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives were eluted with a 0–90% linear gradient of acetonitrile in water or with 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) over 30 min. The derivatives of 1 were chromatographed without the 0.1% TFA. All NMR data were collected on a Bruker AVANCE IIITM HD 500 MHz spectrometer using a 500 MHz SmartProbe. 195Pt NMR data were collected at 107.47 MHz using sw = 217391.3 Hz, aq = 0.002 s, and rd = 0.001 s. The data were processed using MestreNova with a 300 Hz line broadening and backward linear prediction. 1H spectra were recorded with standard parameters and referenced to internal standard TSP when recorded in D2O or residual solvent peak when recorded in DMSO-d6. 13C spectra were not recorded since all the complexes are composed of commercial ligands that are merely coordinated to the Pt center by donation of two electrons to an empty orbital of the metal. No carbon–carbon bonds were broken or formed, and the 13C spectra of the complexes are practically identical to those of the commercially available ligands; therefore, no new information is provided by these spectra. The best characterization of these complexes is the combination of 195Pt NMR that verifies bis-carboxylation of the Pt(IV) combined with the 1H NMR that confirms the ratios between the ligands. This in combination with the HPLC retention times and ESI-MS (when possible) are the best way to characterize the Pt complexes. All the compounds that were used for biological studies were purified by preparative HPLC and then analyzed by analytical HPLC and elemental analysis; their purity was >95%.

    Synthesis

    [Pt(DACH)(OH)2(ox)] (1a)

    This complex was prepared as previously described.(18) Briefly, 1 g (2.51 mmol) of 1 was suspended in 30% H2O2 (10 mL) for 12 h, after which the suspension turned into a clear yellow solution. The solvent was evaporated in vacuo, producing a pale yellow product. Yield: 1.02 g (94%). 195Pt NMR(H2O): +1350 ppm.

    [Pt(DACH)(PhB)(OH)(ox)] (2a)

    A mixture of 393 mg (0.91 mmol) of compound 1a and 312.4 mg (1 mmol) of PhB anhydride was dissolved in 20 mL of DMSO. After 12 h, the cloudy solution turned into a clear dark yellow solution. The mother liquor was treated with diethylether (DEE), affording a two-phase system. The DEE phase was removed after centrifugation. This procedure was repeated several times until a sticky yellow solid was obtained. Then, it was dissolved in methanol and precipitated from DEE as an off-white powder. Yield: 249 mg (47%). 195Pt NMR (DMSO): +1407 ppm.

    [Pt(DACH)(PhB)(OAc)(ox)] (2)

    One hundred milligrams (0.17 mmol) of 2a was dissolved in 5 mL of DMF. One milliliter of acetic anhydride was then added (9.8 mmol, in excess). The reaction was stirred overnight. DMF was removed in vacuo. The oily product was dissolved in methanol and precipitated from cold ether. The crude product was purified by preparative HPLC (0–90% linear acetonitrile gradient over 30 min, retention time = 19.30 min). The collected fraction (in H2O/ACN) was evaporated, resuspended in water, and lyophilized to give a white product. Yield: 63 mg (60%). 195Pt NMR (DMSO): +1585 ppm. 1H NMR δ 7.27 (m, 2HPhB), 7.17 (m, 3HPhB), 3.6 (w, 2HDACH), 2.51 (t, 2HPhB), 2.26 (t, 2HPhB), 2.15 (d, 2HDACH), 1.96 (s, 3Hac), 1.76 (p, 2HPhB), 1.51 (d, 2HDACH), 1.42 (w, 2HDACH), 1.15 (t, 2HDACH). Anal. calcd for C20H28N2O8Pt: C, 38.77; H, 4.56; N, 4.42; found: C, 38.55; H, 4.69; N, 4.41.

    [Pt(DACH)(oct)(OAc)(ox)] (3)

    Two hundred forty milligrams (0.507 mmol) of oxaliplatin(OAc)(OH) (1b) (prepared as described in ref (4)) was dissolved in 20 mL of DMF. Five hundred fifty milligrams (4 equiv in excess) of octanoic anhydride was then added. The reaction was stirred overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was monitored by 195Pt NMR. When the reaction was complete, DMF was evaporated in vacuo, yielding an oily product. The product was suspended in ether and stirred overnight then centrifuged and dried under air. The product was dissolved in methanol and purified by semipreparative HPLC (0–90% linear acetonitrile gradient over 30 min, retention time = 21.4 min). The collected fraction was evaporated using a vacuum then resuspended in water and lyophilized, affording a white powder. Yield: 220 mg (72.4%). 195Pt NMR (DMF): single peak at +1597 ppm. 1H NMR (500 MHz, MeOD) δ 2.76 (m, 2HDACH), 2.34 (m, 2HOct), 2.27 (br, 2HDACH), 2.05 (s, 3HOAc), 1.68 (d, 2HDACH), 1.54 (br, 2HDACH, 2HOct), 1.28 (br, 2HDACH, 8HOct), 0.89 (t, 3HOct). Anal. calcd for C18H32N2O8Pt: C, 36.06; H, 5.38; N, 4.67; found: C, 35.99; H, 5.29; N, 4.42.

    [Pt(DACH)(PhB)(oct)(ox)] (4)

    One hundred milligrams (0.17mmole) of 2a was dissolved in 5 mL of DMF. Octanoic anhydride (190 mg, 4 equiv, 0.69 mmol) was then added. The reaction was stirred for 24 h. DMF was removed in vacuo. The oily product was stirred overnight in DEE, centrifuged, and dried under air. The crude product was purified by semipreparative HPLC (0–100% linear acetonitrile gradient over 15 min, followed by 10 min of acetonitrile plateau; retention time = 17.03 min). The collected fraction (in H2O/ACN) was evaporated, resuspended in water, and lyophilized to give a white product. Yield: 37 mg (31%). 195Pt NMR (DMSO): +1587 ppm. 1H NMR δ 7.29 (m, 2HPhB), 7.17 (m, 3HPhB), 3.6 (w, 2HDACH), 2.51 (t, 2HPhB), 2.50 (m, 4Hoct), 2.26 (t, 2HPhB), 2.15 (d, 2HDACH), 1.86 (m, 6Hoct),1.79 (p, 2HPhB), 1.51 (d, 2HDACH), 1.50 (b, 2Hoct), 1.42 (w,2HDACH), 1.21 (t, 2HDACH), 0.88 (t,3Hoct). Anal. calcd for C26H40N2O8Pt: C, 44.38; H, 5.73; N, 3.98; found: C, 44.25; H, 5.69; N, 4.01.

    [Pt(1S,2S-Diaminocyclohexane)(5,6-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline)]2+ (5)

    5 was synthesized according to a method described in the literature.(79) Acetic anhydride was purchased and used as received. The other anhydrides were synthesized from their respective acids.(17) cct-[Pt(1S,2S-DACH)(5,6-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline)(OH)2] (5a), 6, and 7 were prepared as previously described.(66)

    cct-[Pt(1S,2S-DACH)(5,6-Dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline)(PhB)(oct)] (8)

    5a was stirred in DMSO to obtain a final concentration of ca. 15 mg of Pt complex per milliliter of DMSO. Octanoic anhydride (1.2 equiv) was added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature (RT) in the dark. After one night, the initial yellow suspension turned to a yellow solution. Phenylbutyric anhydride (4 equiv) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred in the dark at RT for another night. When the second carboxylation was complete, the mixture turned to a brown solution that was filtered. The filtrate was diluted with a volume of ethyl acetate, and diethyl ether was added until a two-phase system was obtained. The two phases were separated by centrifugation, and the upper ether phase was removed. Fresh ether was added to the dark bottom phase, stirred, and then allowed to yield a two-phase system; the mixture was centrifuged, and the upper phase was removed. This procedure was repeated until a dark sticky solid was obtained. It was dissolved in methanol, purified on preparative HPLC (5–65% linear acetonitrile gradient over 20 min, retention time = 17.053 min), and lyophilized, obtaining its trifluoroacetate salt. 1H NMR (D2O) δ: 9.44 (d, 2H, H2PHEN), 9.24 (dd, 2H, H4PHEN), 8.33 (m, 2H, H3PHEN), 7.15 (t, 2H, HmetaPhBu), 7.14 (t, 2H, HparaPhBu), 6.50 (d, 2H, HorthoPhBu), 3.23 (m, 2H, HαDACH), 2.75 (s, 6H, CH3PHEN), 2.47 (m, 2H, HβDACH), 2.15 (t, 2H, HαPhBu), 2.08 (t, 2H, CαH3Oct), 1.77 (m, 2H, HβDACH), 1.73 (m, 2H, HγDACH), 1.46 (t, 2H, HγPhBu), 1.34 (m, 2H, HγDACH), 1.26 (t, 2H, HβPhBu), 0.97 (q, 2H, CβH3Oct), 0.88 (q, 2H, CζH2Oct), 0.72 (t, 3H, CηH3Oct), 0.61–0.45 (m, 4H, CδH2Oct and CεH2Oct), 0.12 (b, 2H, CγH3Oct). 195Pt NMR (D2O) δ: 694 ppm. ESI-MS: calculated for [M–H]+ (M++ = C38H51N4O4Pt): m/z = 822.36; experimental: m/z = 822.05. Anal. calcd for: C, 47.11; H, 4.55; N, 5.49: found: C, 46.82; H, 4.73; N, 5.28.

    Cell Lines

    The human cervical carcinoma HeLa cells, human colorectal carcinoma cells HCT-116, human ovarian carcinoma A2780 cells, and human breast cancer MCF-7 cells were kindly supplied by Professor B. Keppler, University of Vienna (Austria). Highly invasive breast carcinoma MDA-MB-231 cells and human MRC-5 pd30 cells derived from normal lung tissue were purchased from the European Collection of Authenticated Cell Cultures (ECACC) (Salisbury, UK). Chinese hamster ovary CHO-K1 cell line (wild type) and its derivative MMC-2 carrying the ERCC3/XPB mutation (NER-deficient) cell line were kindly supplied by Dr. M. Pirsel, Cancer Research Institute, Slovak Academy of Sciences, Bratislava (Slovakia). The A2780 cells were grown in RPMI 1640 medium (Biosera, Boussens, France) supplemented with gentamycin (50 μg mL–1, Serva, Heidelberg, Germany) and 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (PAA, Pasching, Austria). The HeLa, MCF-7, HCT-116, CHO-K1, and MMC-2 cells were grown in DMEM medium (high glucose, 4.5 g L–1, PAA) supplemented with gentamycin (50 μg mL–1, Serva) and 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (PAA). The MDA-MB-231 and MRC-5 pd30 cells were grown in DMEM medium (high glucose, 4.5 g L–1, PAA) supplemented with gentamycin (50 μg mL–1, Serva), 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (PAA), and 1% nonessential amino acids (Sigma-Aldrich, Prague, Czech Republic). The cells were cultured in a humidified incubator at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere and subcultured two to three times a week with an appropriate plating density.

    Antiproliferative Activity

    Antiproliferative activities of the investigated complexes were evaluated by using a system based on the tetrazolium compound MTT from Calbiochem (Darmstadt, Germany). Stock solutions of 1 and 5 were prepared by dissolving the investigated platinum compounds in ultrapure water (Milli-Q, Merck Millipore) to a final concentration of 5 mM. Stock solutions of the other complexes were prepared by dissolving the compounds in DMF to a final concentration of 10 mM. To avoid DMF toxicity, the final DMF concentration in cell culture medium did not exceed 0.5% (v/v). The cells were seeded in 96-well tissue culture plates at a density of 1 × 104 A2780, MRC-5 cells/well, 8 × 103 MCF-7 cells/well, 5 × 103 HeLa, MDA-MB-231, HCT-116, CHO-K1, and MMC-2 cells/well in 100 μL of medium. After overnight incubation (16 h) at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere, the cells were treated with the tested compounds in the concentration range of 0 to 50 μM in a final volume of 200 μL/well. After additional 72 h, 20 μL of a freshly diluted MTT solution (1.25 mg mL–1 in PBS) was added to each well, and the plates were incubated at 37 °C in a humidified 5% CO2 atmosphere for 4 h. At the end of the incubation period, the medium was removed, and the formazan product was dissolved in 100 μL of DMSO. The cell viability was evaluated by measurement of the absorbance at 570 nm (reference, 620 nm) using an absorbance reader (SUNRISE TECAN, SCHOELLER). All experiments were made in triplicate. The reading values were converted to the percentage of control (% cell survival). Cytotoxic effects were expressed as IC50 values calculated from the curves constructed by plotting cell survival (%) versus drug concentration (μM) (IC50 = concentration of the agent inhibiting cell growth by 50%). Concentrations of Pt complexes present in the medium during treatment were verified by flameless atomic absorption spectrometry (FAAS).

    Cellular Accumulation

    Cellular accumulation of the investigated complexes was determined in highly invasive human breast carcinoma cells MDA-MB-231. In these experiments, 2 × 106 MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded on 100 mm Petri dishes. After overnight preincubation in a drug-free medium at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere, the cells were treated with the platinum compounds at the indicated concentrations for the given periods (37 °C, 5% CO2). After the treatment, the cells were extensively washed with PBS (37 °C), detached using 0.25% trypsin, and washed twice with ice-cold PBS. The cell pellets were stored at −70 °C and digested using a microwave acid (HCl) digestion system (CEM Mars). The quantity of platinum taken up by the cells was determined by ICP-MS. All experiments were carried out in triplicate.

    Measurement of the Partition Coefficients

    To determine the partition coefficients (P) of the investigated compounds, the “shake flask” method was used. Octanol-saturated water (OSW) and water-saturated octanol (WSO) were prepared using analytical grade octanol and ultrapure water. Platinum complexes were dissolved in OSW containing 200 mM NaCl and mixed with WSO in volumetric ratios of 2:1, 1:1, and 1:2. Mixing was done by vortexing for 30 min at room temperature to establish the partition equilibrium. To separate the phases, the samples were centrifuged at 3000g for 5 min. The layers were separated carefully using a fine-tip pipet and then analyzed for metal content by FAAS. The partition coefficients were calculated as a ratio of the concentration of the compound in the octanol layer to that in the aqueous layer [log P = log ([Pt]WSO/[Pt]OSW)].

    Platinum Distribution in Subcellular Compartments

    MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded on Petri dishes at a density of 2 × 106 cells/dish and incubated overnight. After the following treatment with the platinum compounds, the cells were washed twice with PBS and pelleted. The isolation of individual fractions was carried out according to the manufacturer’s protocol (FractionPREP Cell Fractionation kit; BioVision). The platinum content in the separated fractions (cytosolic, membrane/particulate, nuclear, and cytoskeletal) was determined by ICP-MS. The experiment was carried out in triplicate.

    Quantification of Platinum Bound to DNA

    Quantification in a Cell-Free Medium

    Calf thymus DNA (64 μg mL–1) was incubated with 2 × 10–5 M 5, 1, or their Pt(IV) derivatives in 10 mM NaClO4 at 37 °C in the presence or absence of 2 × 10–5 M sodium ascorbate. Then, the free (unbound) platinum in these samples was removed by gel filtration using Sephadex G-25, and the samples were redissolved in double distilled water. DNA concentration and platinum contents in these samples were determined with the aid of UV and flameless atomic absorption spectrophotometry, respectively.

    Quantification in DNA Isolated from the Cells

    MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with the tested compounds at a concentration of 2 μM for 6 h. The cell pellets were stored at −70 °C and then lysed in DNAzol (DNAzol, MRC) supplemented with RNase A (100 μg mL–1). Genomic DNA was precipitated from the lysate by 100% ethanol, washed twice with 75% ethanol, and resuspended in 8 mM NaOH. The DNA content in each sample was determined by UV spectrophotometry. To avoid the affection of high DNA concentration on detection of platinum in the samples, the DNA samples were digested in the presence of 30% hydrochloric acid (Suprapur, Merck Millipore). The amount of metal bound to nucleic acids was quantified by ICP-MS. All measurements were done in triplicate.

    Real-Time Cell Growth Monitoring

    Real-time cell analyzer (RTCA) (xCELLigence RTCA SP Instrument, ROCHE) was employed for growth monitoring of MDA-MB-231 cells in the absence and presence of the investigated compounds. After the background of E-plate reading (100 μL medium), the cells were added (5 × 103 cells/well; 50 μL) and grown for 22–28 h. The investigated compounds at various concentrations were then added in 50 μL of media. The impedance was monitored for additional 4 days. An arbitrary unit CI (cell index) is a quantitative measure reflecting the status of the cells (number of attached cells and cell status such as morphology) in an electrode-containing well. Normalized CI at a certain time point is given by dividing CI at the time point by CI at a reference time point.

    Flow Cytometric Analysis of the Cell Cycle

    MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded at a density of 5 × 105 cells/well in six-well culture plates. After overnight preincubation in a drug-free medium, the cells were treated for 12, 24, and 48 h with the investigated compounds at final concentrations corresponding to IC30 values determined for 72 h of treatment. Treated and untreated cells were harvested by trypsinization, washed twice with PBS, resuspended in 70% ethanol, and kept at 4 °C overnight. Fixed cells were rinsed twice in PBS and stained with propidium iodide diluted to 50 μg mL–1 in Vindel’s solution (10 mM Tris-Cl, pH 8.0, 10 mM NaCl, 0.1% Triton X-100, and 100 μg mL–1 RNase A) for 30 min at 37 °C. Cell-cycle profiles were measured with a FACS Verse flow cytometer (Becton Dickinson, Germany) and data analyzed using ModFit LT 4.1 software (Verity Software House). Results were confirmed in three independent experiments.

    Cytoskeleton Organization

    MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded on glass-bottom culture dishes (MatTek Corporation, Ashland, MA, USA) at a density of 1 × 105 cells/dish. After overnight preincubation in a drug-free medium, the cells were treated with the tested compounds for the indicated periods. Following the treatment, the cells were washed twice in PBS and fixed in 100% methanol (ice-cold; 2 min). Methanol was then removed, and the cells were permeabilized with PBST buffer (0.1% Tween-20 in PBS) for 20 min. Following the permeabilization, blocking solution was applied (10% normal donkey serum in PBST) for 1 h. The primary antibody (anti-α-tubulin; mouse; Sigma-Aldrich, Prague, Czech Republic; 150:1 dilution) was incubated at room temperature for 2 h. After four washes with PBST, the secondary antibody was added (Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-mouse; Invitrogen, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Prague, Czech Republic; 2 drops/mL dilution) and incubated for 1 h. Cells were washed five times with PBST, and ProLongTM Gold antifade reagent with DAPI (4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole dihydrochloride, Invitrogen, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Prague, Czech Republic) was applied. The images were taken with the laser-scanning microscope Leica TCS SP8 SMD (Leica Microsystems GmbH, Wetzlar, Germany).

    Tubulin Polymerization Assay

    Tubulin polymerization was studied in the absence or presence of 5 and its Pt(IV) derivatives using the HTS-Tubulin Polymerization Assay Biochem Kit (Cytoskeleton, Inc.) following the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, 4 mg mL–1 porcine brain tubulin in general tubulin buffer with or without platinum compounds at the indicated concentrations was filled in spectrophotometry cuvettes and warmed to 37 °C. The reaction was started by the addition of GTP to a final concentration of 1 mM. The signal was read at 340 nm for at least 60 min on the UV–VIS Spectrophotometer Varian Cary 4000.

    Tubulin Depolymerization Assay

    Tubulin was polymerized following the above procedure with or without platinum compounds. After 80 min at 37 °C, the temperature was decreased down to 17 °C (0.5 °C/min). The signal was read at 340 nm.

    Whole Cell Analysis of Microtubule by Flow Cytometry

    MDA-MB-231 cells were grown in six-well plates overnight and then incubated with the investigated compounds for 3 h at the concentrations of 20, 40, or 80 μM. After incubation, the cells were harvested by trypsinization, pelleted, and fixed in 1 mL of 0.5% glutaraldehyde in microtubule stabilizing buffer (MTSB: 80 mM Pipes, pH 6.8, 1 mM MgCl2, 5 mM EDTA, and 0.5% Triton X-100). After 10 min at room temperature, 0.7 mL of NaBH4 in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) was added to quench glutaraldehyde. The cells were pelleted again and resuspended in 20 μL of 50 μg mL–1 RNase A in antibody diluting solution (PBS, pH 7.4, 0.2% Triton X-100, 2% BSA, and 0.1% NaN3) and incubated overnight (4 °C). The next day, the cells were incubated with the anti-α-tubulin-FITC antibody (mouse monoclonal; Sigma-Aldrich, Prague; 1:250 dilution) in antibody diluting solution in the dark for 3 h. The cells were vortexed and analyzed by flow cytometry. Tubulin levels based on the geometric mean of FITC fluorescence were normalized to 100% for the control.

    AFM Imaging of Microtubules

    Porcine brain tubulin (Cytoskeleton, Inc.) was polymerized following the same procedure as in the tubulin polymerization assay for 80–90 min. An aliquot was withdrawn, and the microtubules were fixed with 0.1% glutaraldehyde (final concentration). The solution was diluted 40× in general tubulin buffer, and a droplet (4 μL) was spotted directly onto freshly cleaved mica (SPI, West Chester, PA) and incubated for 2 min at room temperature. The mica was gently rinsed with Milli-Q water (0.5 mL) and immediately blown dry with compressed air. Imaging was carried out in air using a Bruker MultiMode 8 atomic force microscope operated in ScanAsyst-HR mode and SCANASYST-AIR-HR probes (Bruker, Santa Barbara, CA).

    Mitochondrial Membrane Depolarization

    MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded on 96-well plates at a density of 1 × 104 cells/well and incubated overnight. The medium was removed, and the cells were treated with the platinum compounds in RPMI 1640 (without phenol red) at the given concentrations for the given periods. The medium was removed, and the cells were washed with PBS. Following the TMRE staining (1 nM, 20 min, 0.2% BSA in PBS), the plate was read to measure TMRE fluorescence (excitation/emission = 560 nm/595 nm) on Varian Cary Eclipse. The samples were read in quadruplicate, and the experiment was repeated thrice.

    HDAC Activity Analysis

    The activity of HDAC enzymes was analyzed in MDA-MB-231 cells treated with the investigated compounds. The activity of HDAC was analyzed with the HDAC fluorimetric cellular activity assay kit (Enzo Life Sciences; Farmingdale, NY) in the whole cells following the manufacturer’s protocol. Briefly, the cells were grown in culture media without phenol red. After reaching 80% confluence, the cells were incubated with the tested compounds and the HDAC substrate for 4 h. Samples were treated in octuplicate, and the experiment was performed in triplicate. The HDAC reaction was terminated by addition of 2 μM trichostatin A and further incubation for 15 min at 37 °C with the developer. The generated fluorescence signal was read on a fluorescence reader Infinite 200 (TECAN) (360 nm excitation/ 460 nm emission).

    DNA Methylation Analysis

    MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded at the density of 2 × 106 cells/dish. Cells were harvested following 24 h of incubation with the investigated compounds. Cell pellets were lysed with DNAzol (DNAzol genomic DNA isolation reagent, MRC) supplemented with RNase A (100 μg mL–1). The genomic DNA was precipitated with ethanol, washed, and redissolved in water. The DNA content in each sample was determined spectrophotometrically. DNA (0.2 mg) from each sample was used in the Imprint methylated DNA quantification kit (Sigma-Aldrich, USA). The level of DNA methylation was proportional to the 450 nm absorbance. The signals of individual samples were normalized to the control and expressed in percentage.

      Modifications of DNA by platinum complexes
      Brabec, Viktor; Kasparkova, Jana
      Drug Resistance Updates (2005), 8 (3), 131-146CODEN: DRUPFW; ISSN:1368-7646. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. The importance of platinum drugs in cancer chemotherapy is underscored by the clin. success of cisplatin [cis-diamminedichloroplatinum(II)] and its analogs and by clin. trials of other, less toxic platinum complexes that are active against resistant tumors. The antitumor effect of platinum complexes is believed to result from their ability to form various types of adducts with DNA. Nevertheless, drug resistance can occur by several ways: increased drug efflux, drug inactivation, alterations in drug target, processing of drug-induced damage, and evasion of apoptosis. This review focuses on mechanisms of resistance and sensitivity of tumors to conventional cisplatin assocd. with DNA modifications. We also discuss mol. mechanisms underlying resistance and sensitivity of tumors to the new platinum compds. synthesized with the goal to overcome resistance of tumors to established platinum drugs. Importantly, a no. of new platinum compds. were designed to test the hypothesis that there is a correlation between the extent of resistance of tumors to these agents and their ability to induce a certain kind of damage or conformational change in DNA. Hence, information on DNA-binding modes, as well as recognition and repair of DNA damage is discussed, since this information may be exploited for improved structure-activity relationships.

      de Lera, A. R.; Ganesan, A. Epigenetic polypharmacology: from combination therapy to multitargeted drugs. Clin. Epigenet. 2016, 8, 105,  DOI: 10.1186/s13148-016-0271-9

      Epigenetic polypharmacology: from combination therapy to multitargeted drugs
      de Lera, Angel R.; Ganesan, A.
      Clinical Epigenetics (2016), 8 (), 105/1-105/21CODEN: CELPCI; ISSN:1868-7083. (BioMed Central Ltd.)
      A review. The modern drug discovery process has largely focused its attention in the so-called magic bullets, single chem. entities that exhibit high selectivity and potency for a particular target. This approach was based on the assumption that the deregulation of a protein was causally linked to a disease state, and the pharmacol. intervention through inhibition of the deregulated target was able to restore normal cell function. However, the use of cocktails or multicomponent drugs to address several targets simultaneously is also popular to treat multifactorial diseases such as cancer and neurol. disorders. We review the state of the art with such combinations that have an epigenetic target as one of their mechanisms of action. Epigenetic drug discovery is a rapidly advancing field, and drugs targeting epigenetic enzymes are in the clinic for the treatment of hematol. cancers. Approved and exptl. epigenetic drugs are undergoing clin. trials in combination with other therapeutic agents via fused or linked pharmacophores in order to benefit from synergistic effects of polypharmacol. In addn., ligands are being discovered which, as single chem. entities, are able to modulate multiple epigenetic targets simultaneously (multitarget epigenetic drugs). These multiple ligands should in principle have a lower risk of drug-drug interactions and drug resistance compared to cocktails or multicomponent drugs. This new generation may rival the so-called magic bullets in the treatment of diseases that arise as a consequence of the deregulation of multiple signaling pathways provided the challenge of optimization of the activities shown by the pharmacophores with the different targets is addressed.

      Ganesan, A. Multitarget drugs: an epigenetic epiphany. ChemMedChem 2016, 11, 1227– 1241,  DOI: 10.1002/cmdc.201500394

      Multitarget Drugs: an Epigenetic Epiphany
      Ganesan, A.
      ChemMedChem (2016), 11 (12), 1227-1241CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Epigenetics refers to changes in a biol. phenotype that are not due to an underlying change in genotype. In eukaryotes, epigenetics involves a set of chem. modifications of the DNA and the histone proteins in nucleosomes. These dynamic changes are carried out by enzymes and modulate protein-protein and protein-nucleic acid interactions to det. whether specific genes are expressed or silenced. Both the epigenetic enzymes and recognition domains are currently important drug discovery targets, particularly for the treatment of cancer. This review summarizes the progress of epigenetic targets that have reached a clin. stage: DNA methyltransferases, histone deacetylases, lysine methyltransferases, lysine demethylases, and bromodomains; this is followed by a comprehensive survey of multitarget drugs that have included an epigenetic target as one of their mechanisms of action.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Polypharmacology: Challenges and Opportunities in Drug Discovery
      Anighoro, Andrew; Bajorath, Jurgen; Rastelli, Giulio
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2014), 57 (19), 7874-7887CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. At present, the legendary magic bullet, i.e., a drug with high potency and selectivity toward a specific biol. target, shares the spotlight with an emerging and alternative polypharmacol. approach. Polypharmacol. suggests that more effective drugs can be developed by specifically modulating multiple targets. It is generally thought that complex diseases such as cancer and central nervous system diseases may require complex therapeutic approaches. In this respect, a drug that "hits" multiple sensitive nodes belonging to a network of interacting targets offers the potential for higher efficacy and may limit drawbacks generally arising from the use of a single-target drug or a combination of multiple drugs. In this review, we will compare advantages and disadvantages of multitarget vs. combination therapies, discuss potential drug promiscuity arising from off-target effects, comment on drug repurposing, and introduce approaches to the computational design of multitarget drugs.

      Polypharmacology - Foe or Friend?
      Peters, Jens-Uwe
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2013), 56 (22), 8955-8971CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Polypharmacol. describes the activity of compds. at multiple targets. Current research focuses on two aspects of polypharmacol.: (1) unintended polypharmacol. can lead to adverse effects; (2) polypharmacol. across several disease-relevant targets can improve therapeutic efficacy, prevent drug resistance, or reduce therapeutic-target-related adverse effects. This perspective reviews these interconnected aspects of polypharmacol. The first part discusses the relevance of polypharmacol. for the safety of drugs, the mitigation of safety risks, and methods to identify polypharmacol. compds. early in the drug discovery process. The second part discusses the advantages of polypharmacol. in the treatment of multigenic diseases and infections, and opportunities for drug discovery and drug repurposing. This perspective aims to provide a balanced view on polypharmacol., which can compromise the safety of drugs, but can also confer superior efficacy.

      Platinum(IV) anticancer prodrugs - hypotheses and facts
      Gibson, Dan
      Dalton Transactions (2016), 45 (33), 12983-12991CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      In this manuscript we focus on Pt(IV) anticancer prodrugs. We explore the main working hypotheses for the design of effective Pt(IV) prodrugs and note the exceptions to the common assumptions that are prevalent in the field. Special attention was devoted to the emerging class of "dual action" Pt(IV) prodrugs, where bioactive ligands are conjugated to the axial positions of platinum in order to obtain orthogonal or complementary effects that will increase the efficacy of killing the cancer cells. We discuss the rationale behind the design of the "dual action" prodrugs and the results of the pharmacol. studies obtained. Simultaneous release of two bioactive moieties inside the cancer cells often triggers several processes that together det. the fate of the cell. Pt(IV) complexes provide many opportunities for applying new concepts in targeting, synergistic cell killing and exploiting novel nanodelivery systems.
